'''''Ramaria formosa''''', commonly known as the '''beautiful clavaria''', '''handsome clavaria''', '''yellow-tipped-''' or '''pink coral fungus''', is a [[coral fungus]] found in Asia, Europe and North America. It is widely held to be mildly [[poisonous mushroom|poisonous]] if consumed, giving rise to acute gastrointestinal symptoms of nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea and colicky pain. It is a pinkish, much-branched coral-shape reaching some {{convert|20|cm|in|0|abbr=on|lk=on|sigfig=1}} high. Some forms collected in North America often lack the bitter taste common to European specimens and may represent a different species.

==Taxonomy==
The fungus was initially [[species description|described]] by [[Christian Hendrik Persoon]] in 1797 as ''Clavaria formosa''.<ref name="Persoon 1797"/> In 1821, [[Elias Magnus Fries]] [[sanctioned name|sanctioned]] the genus name ''[[Clavaria]]'', and treated ''[[Ramaria]]'' as a [[section (biology)|section]] of ''Clavaria''.<ref name="Fries 1821"/> It was placed in its current [[genus]] by French mycologist [[Lucien Quélet]] in 1888.<ref name="Quélet 1888"/> [[Synonym (taxonomy)|Synonyms]] have resulted from transfers of the fungus to the now obsolete genera ''Merisma'' by [[Harald Othmar Lenz]] in 1831,<ref name="Lenz 1831"/> and to ''Corallium'' by [[Gotthold Hahn]] in 1883.<ref name="Hahn 1883"/>

The generic name is derived from [[Latin]] ''rāmus'' 'branch', while the [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] comes from the [[Latin]] ''formōsus'' 'beautiful'.<ref name="Simpson 1979"/> [[Common name]]s include salmon coral,<ref name="BMS"/> beautiful clavaria, handsome clavaria,<ref name="Hladký 1996"/> yellow-tipped- or pink coral fungus.<ref name="Bresinsky 1990"/>  There is some confusion over its classification as there is evidence the binomial name has been applied loosely to any coral fungus fitting the description, and thus some collections from North America may be a different species.<ref name="Ammirati 1985"/>

==Description==
The [[Basidiocarp|fruit body]] of ''Ramaria formosa'' grows to a height of {{convert|30|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} and width of {{convert|15|cm|in|0|abbr=on}};<ref name="Phillips 2006"/> it is a many-branched [[Clavarioid fungi|coral-like structure]], the yellow-tipped pinkish branches arising from a thick base.<ref name="Zeitlmayr 1976"/> Terminal branches are less than {{convert|0.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} in diameter. The flesh is white, with pink in the middle,<ref name="Zeitlmayr 1976"/> or pale orange. It may turn [[Wine color|wine-coloured]] or blackish when bruised.<ref name="Phillips 2006"/> Old specimens may fade so the original colour is hard to distinguish. The smell is unpleasant and taste bitter.<ref name="Zeitlmayr 1976"/> However, the taste has been reported as indistinct in North American collections. Old specimens dry out and become brittle and chalk-like, so that rubbing the branches between one's fingers crumbles them into powder.<ref name="Ammirati 1985"/>
[[File:Ramaria formosa spores 1000x.JPG|thumb|left|Spores at 1000x magnifaction]]
''Ramaria formosa'' produces a golden-yellow [[spore print]].<ref name="Ammirati 1985"/> The [[basidiospore|spores]] have a cylindrical to elliptical shape, and measure 8–15 by 4–6 [[micrometre|µm]]. The spore surface features small warts that are arranged in confluent lines. [[Basidia]] (spore-bearing cells) are club-shaped, measuring 40–60 by 7–10 µm,<ref name="Courtecuisse 1999"/> and have one to four sterigmata. In the stalk, the hyphae comprising the flesh are interwoven, while hyphae in the branches have a more parallel arrangement. Both types measure 4–13 µm wide. Some of the hyphae are gloeoplerous, meaning they have an oily or granular appearance when viewed under the microscope.<ref name="Ammirati 1985"/> [[Clamp connection]]s are present in the hyphae. [[Chemical tests in mushroom identification#Iron salts|Iron salts]] applied to the branches will cause a green colour change.<ref name="Kuo 2014"/>

===Similar species===
In Europe, it could be confused with two edible yellow coral fungi—the high yellow clavaria (''[[Ramaria flava]]'') and ''[[Ramaria aurea|R. aurea]]''. These have pale golden yellow flesh in their branches, unlike the white flesh of ''R. formosa''. However, this difference can be hard to make out.<ref name="Nilper 1977"/> A general rule is to avoid all old coral fungi.<ref name="Zeitlmayr 1976"/> The North American species ''[[Ramaria largentii|R. largentii]]'' has orange branches.<ref name="Davis 2012"/> There are several other ''Ramaria'' species with yellow-tipped, salmon-coloured branches, including ''[[Ramaria leptoformosa|R. leptoformosa]]'', ''[[Ramaria neoformosa|R. neoformosa]]'', ''[[Ramaria raveneliana|R. raveneliana]]'' and  ''[[Ramaria rubricarnata|R. rubricarnata]]''. These are distinguished from ''R. formosa'' most reliably using microscopic characteristics.<ref name="Davis 2012"/><ref name="Roberts 2011"/><!-- Roberts ref covers first 3 species and Davis book covers rubricarnata-->

==Distribution and habitat==
Fruiting in autumn, ''Ramaria formosa'' is associated with [[beech]] and is found in Asia ([[Yunnan]], China<ref name="Petersen 1989"/> and India<ref name="Shah 2015"/>), Europe,<ref name="Nilper 1977"/> and North America. Forms from the western areas are known to occur under conifers.<ref name="Ammirati 1985"/> In [[Cyprus]], the fungus is thought to form [[mycorrhiza]]l associations with [[golden oak]] (''Quercus alnifolia'').<ref name="Loizides 2011"/>

==Toxicity==
Consumption of the fungus results in acute gastrointestinal symptoms of nausea, vomiting, [[colic]]ky abdominal pain and diarrhea. The toxins responsible are unknown to date. It has been reported as edible if the acrid tips are removed.<ref name="North 1967"/> Toxicity notwithstanding, the fungus is used as a [[traditional medicine]] by the [[Gurjar]] and [[Bakarwal]] tribes in the [[Rajouri district|Rajouri]] and [[Poonch district, India|Poonch]] districts of India. Fruit bodies are eaten with food after cooking, in the belief that they relieve body pain.<ref name="Shah 2015"/> The fungus is also sold in markets in [[Lijiang]], China.<ref name="Petersen 1989"/>
